I teach math to adults, focusing a lot on pre-algebra, and much of my time is spent convincing students that we can discover the rules of algebra through our understanding of basic arithmetic. One of the largest obstacles for students who don't do well in math is that they have learned it as a set of rules and procedures that they just memorize without any justification. That is exactly what Dragonbox Algebra 5+ teaches. It doesn't give any context or meaning to the equations, it just treats the equations as abstract objects. Therefore, there is no *reason* for the rules, they are just rules to be memorized. In addition, contrary to how math is actually done, in this game there is generally only one way to solve a given equation. For example, I was given x+a/b=c. Whereas the one-step procedure for this is to subtract a/b from both sides, this app doesn't allow subtracting fractions, so you have to first multiply everything by a, then subtract b, and then divide everything by a. Absurd. I love Dragonbox Numbers and Big Numbers and Elements because they emphasize meaning and creativity and flexibility. This one may well be more damaging than it is helpful.
Not the game I originally bought.  They dumbed it down and added more versions that they are selling.  I would never have bought this with how it is now.
replyContent: Jim, sorry but you are mistaken. DragonBox Algebra 5+ (originally named DragonBox+) has always contained the same levels. We can give you the APKs for the 18 different releases made since 2012 if you want to check them all. If you do prefer to use DragonBox Algebra 12+, feel free to ask and we will sent it for free. Feel free to revise your review.

content: My two daughters (6 and 10 when they started it) loved this game, and even though my son (who is older) breezed through it, he loved it too. My youngest continues to ask to play. I even enjoyed playing it! I've seen other reviews complaining about the dark aesthetic of the game, but my kids all loved it and thought the monsters were cute.
This game is THE BEST! It is very fun and a good teaching tool. Appropriate for little kids too.

My 3 year old DAUGHTER and 10 year old Step DAUGHTER both love this, and think the monsters are adorable. Things don't need to have rainbows and kittens and sugar to be cute, and there is nothing wrong with this game just how it is, whether it is for your girl, boy, or yourself.   We find this game delightful and engaging, love the art and character choices, and think the dragons just get cuter and cuter as they "grow".  The Game moves at a great pace- cementing skills before moving forward- and the "show me the solution" keeps it from getting overly frustrating.  The game is re-playable, and charming.

For everyone else, you just learn to play the game even though you may be unaware that you are balancing an algebraic equation each time. You just need to substitute numbers and variables in for the characters and there you have it. Brilliant! My children ages 8, 9 and 11 love it.

After trying it myself, and with my son, I think that the game is generally way overrated.  Yes, it teaches algebra, and yes, in a kind of a semi-fun way (read: still no competition for your average mind-numbing jump+duck game). But the thing is that the actual algebra that it teaches is a *very* thin mask over the real thing.  In other words, playing with this is not much different from playing with the real thing, and I don't think that the visual fluffiness helps much in teaching.  (Before anyone takes that as nonsense, consider a comparison of the game with a touch-based interface for plain algebra, not with the pencil+paper thing you do at school.) In addition to this, I've only done the first two chapters myself, and already seen two educational bugs: when the minus sign is introduced as an alternative to reverse colors, and when a 0 is introduced instead of the green swirl icon.  In both of these cases, the change is done with no explanation, so it requires an adult's help.  My guess is that if you're expecting the game to work miracles for your kid/s without you working too, then get ready to be disappointed.
replyContent: Hello Eli, thanks for the feedback! The educational bugs are in fact features. Most kids, because they basically need to explore things, do not need or use the explanations. For more information on our intent, see http://support.dragonboxapp.com/knowledgebase/articles/84627-where-is-the-math- Thanks!

replyContent: Julie, we're sorry that you feel disappointed. About the length: the game is designed for children in mind. Our goal was for the user to learn/play in as less time as possible. As for the price, the game is cheaper than a movie ticket, and has 4 profiles for the family to play in turn. 2 stars for a great game for kids, that won't help us much! :)

I really like the idea of learning math symbolically and I hope my 4-year old is learning from the game. He seems to get better over time, so he is picking something up. And, he enjoys it.  Dragonbox uses the cancellation of matching shapes to teach concepts of algebra. Basically, it is matching with a few extra operations. 1. Inverse: each image has an opposite (light/dark for images, a/-a for symbols). As you advance, you can switch a symbol to its inverse. 2. Cancellation by addition: you can put an inverse on top of top of the normal image to 'zero' them (initially taught as a disappearing symbol). 3. Cancellation by multiplication (division): put a symbol underneath a match, then drag on top to create a unity symbol (1). These three operations are combined in more and more complicated orders to simplify each level and isolate the free variable (a box, then later 'x').
Really innovative and works well. Very interesting too.
Far too short for the money, and some iffy glitch graphic. Otherwise a great way of presenting algebra.
replyContent: Oliver, thanks for the feedback. What kind of graphical glitches did you see ? Please send us a screenshot and device model information. We haven't seen glitches on our devices!

This app does a great job of isolating the concepts of algebra so that they don't get muddled up by the arithmetic.  I can see how this could be a useful teaching tool for teaching the abstract concepts and rules of algebra to kids (and adults), though it won't necessarily help them truly understand it. In other words, it teaches the "How", but not the "Why".  I'd love to see the game take its instuctional capabilities to that level.  Keep up the great work!
Har spilt igjennom spillet og det er utrolig bra bygd opp. Progresjonen fra det konkrete til det abstrakte skjer gradvis og uten at man merker det. HÃ¥per dere utvider spillet enda mer. TOPPERS!

Crashed on first run on my SGSII, but now works. Wow, I really love the concept of this game, but it needs so much improvement.  * background music gets annoying after a while, so please add more songs.  Maybe change for each puzzle? Level? They should be of the quiet, meditative (nondisturbing) kind. * Please provide an option to turn the music OFF! * If I solve a puzzle in a convoluted way, I'd love the option for the game to show me the optimum way * I f I try to do an illegal move, I'm prevented and that's fine. But I would love for the game to state the rule that is in effect as well. * I would reconsider the icons used for Undo and Restart. Think Office-suites. * There should be A LOT more puzzles for the asking price! If it's just math, shouldn't the game be able to generate new random puzzles? It's not like each puzzle requires tons of new effort from an artist.  I hope the company at some point attempts to prove the claims how this helps students learn algebra (conduct scientific study?). Playing with it for an hour does not convince.
